title: U.K. Market at Its Most Inconsistent as Regional Price Growth Fluctuates
text:
Despite overall property prices creeping up in the U.K., the country’s real estate market is now at its most inconsistent, according to a report Tuesday from Carter Jonas.



There is a drastic disparity in property price growth among regions due to their respective house price-to-earnings ratio, the estate agent and property consultants said in their annual report.



More: Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas Buy and Sell in the New York Suburbs

The disparity has led many buyers to turn elsewhere in search of better value for money.



As a result, there has been notable price growth in more affordable regions, led by Yorkshire and the Humber, which logged annual rises of 3.6%, along with the West Midlands (up 3.4%) and Wales (3%).



Meanwhile more affluent regions are facing either flat or declining prices including London, where prices have fallen 1.9%, and the South East, which has seen falls of 0.4%, the report said.



“While market performance continues to fluctuate among regions at a level never quite seen before, it is important to recognise that the more affordable areas such as Yorkshire and the Humber continue to harbor opportunity and appeal,” Lisa Simon, head of residential sales at Carter Jonas, said in the report.

“However, the fluctuations in markets that we are seeing are more complex than a simple north-south divide,” she said. “Buyers are fundamentally in search of value and the market is being supported by first-time buyers, who are currently the most active group in the market.”



Despite the regional inconsistencies, and the continuing Brexit uncertainty, overall growth is a positive indicator, Ms. Simon said.

The report did not specify what the overall annual growth level was, or what time frame the data covered.
